description: Derived from the Latin oculāris (“of the eye”), from oculus (“eye”).

adjectives.description: ocular (comparative more ocular, superlative most ocular)

entries.meaning: Of, or relating to the eye, or the sense of sight
examples: The medication may have adverse ocular side effects.
It took some time after he lost his eye for him to receive his ocular prosthesis.
ocular markings on the wings of a butterfly

entries.meaning: Seen by, or seeing with, the eye; visual.
examples: For as Thomas was an ocular Witness of Christ’s Death and Burial, so were the other Disciples of his Resurrection; having actually seen him after he was risen.

entries.meaning: The eyepiece of a microscope or other optical instrument.
Any of the scales forming the margin of a reptile's eye.
